message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest lumbar spinal stenosis or disc herniation, and an MRI of the lumbosacral spine is the best next step in management to confirm the diagnosis. An ankle-brachial index is used to assess peripheral arterial disease, which is not likely the cause of the patient's symptoms based on the normal pulses. Naproxen is a pain reliever and does not address the underlying cause of the patient's symptoms. Radiography of the lumbosacral spine may show bony changes, but an MRI is better for evaluating soft tissues such as herniated discs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the possibility of spinal stenosis, a condition where the spinal canal narrows and compresses the spinal cord and nerve roots. The best next step for management is an MRI of the lumbosacral spine, as it is the most sensitive imaging study for detecting spinal stenosis. Ankle-brachial index is used to assess peripheral arterial disease, which is not consistent with the symptoms presented. Naproxen is a pain reliever and does not address the underlying cause of the symptoms. Radiography of the lumbosacral spine has poor sensitivity and specificity for detecting spinal stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest lumbar spinal stenosis as it worsens with standing and improves with sitting. The MRI of the lumbosacral spine is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis. Ankle-brachial index and radiography of the lumbosacral spine are not useful for this condition. Naproxen can provide symptomatic relief but does not address the underlying cause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest spinal stenosis, which is a narrowing of the spinal canal that typically leads to symptoms of neurogenic claudication. An MRI of the lumbosacral spine is the best next step in management to confirm the diagnosis. Ankle-brachial index, naproxen, and radiography are not indicated in the management of spinal stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest lumbar spinal stenosis, which can be confirmed with an MRI of the lumbosacral spine. An ankle-brachial index is used to assess peripheral vascular disease and is not indicated in this case. Naproxen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that can be used for pain relief but does not address the underlying issue. Radiography of the lumbosacral spine may not provide enough detail to diagnose lumbar spinal stenosis.

Radiography is less sensitive than MRI in diagnosing lumbar spinal stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest spinal stenosis, a common cause of back pain in older adults. An MRI of the lumbosacral spine is the best next step in management to confirm or rule out the diagnosis. Ankle-brachial index is used to diagnose peripheral arterial disease, which is less likely given the normal pulses. Naproxen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug that can help with pain but does not address the underlying cause. Radiography may not provide enough detail and sensitivity to diagnose spinal stenosis.
